prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request a sensitivity of 2.5mJy in 3 km/s bins, which will allow us to detect the prominent line components to many sigma and also provides a good balance between time on source and overheads. Although maser sources are known to be variable, we also anticipate being able to detect the less prominent line components, based on previous 22 GHz observations, and we will be able to average in frequency if necessary, at the expense of kinematic information. We have included 3 spectral windows at lower spectral resolution which are expected to be largely line-free, which we can combine to image dust and synchrotron emission, but primarily these are intended to increase the sensitivity on gain and amplitude calibrators to ensure the best possible calibration.

We require reasonably high spectral resolution (~1km/s) over a broad bandwidth (1875 MHz) in the expectation that the maser emission in these sources will consist of very narrow components covering a large velocity range. This is clearly seen in 22GHz circumnuclear masers which show extremely compact masing clumps which are both red- and blue-shifted with respect to the systemic velocity. For line components that are sufficiently bright, we will be able to spectrally separate them to gain additional kinematic information, while for faint components, such as those found near the systemic velocity, we will have the option of averaging over multiple components to gain sensitivity.

Imaging is not a high priority for this project at this time. Any angular resolution will be useful, although we have a mild preference for a compact configuration in order to facilitate calibration, as observations of water lines, though clearly scientifically important, can be subject to phase noise due to water in our atmosphere for galaxies at moderately low redshift. Following initial detections, we will be able to follow up with high resolution observations in Cycle 4, when long baselines are expected be available for Band 7.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
We propose to observe the water maser transitions at 321 in 5 galaxies in which large abundances of water have been detected. Since the discovery of water maser emission three decades ago, the only concerted extragalactic surveys have been carried out at 22 GHz. Extending the study to other water maser transitions is crucial to understanding the excitation conditions of the water molecule and to provide constraints on the models of pumping mechanisms. Only through constructing a comprehensive model of these physical conditions can we hope to obtain an accurate picture of the central parsecs of active galactic nuclei and the regions of most intense star formation in starburst galaxies.
This proposal is a resubmission of Cycle 2 proposal 2013.1.01222.S. The Cycle 2 SBs have been prepared by ARC staff but not yet observed, and so if they are observed in Cycle 2, they will not need to be repeated.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: North American ALMA Science Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: North American ALMA Science Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory
